text: CLOSE UP on the face of YURI ORLOV. Late-thirties, maybe the wrong side of forty, cigarette d from his fingers, wearing a conservative suit and tie. Black smoke wafts in front of his face.  He speaks matter directly into camera.
There are over 550 million firearms in worldwide circulation.  That's one firearm for every twelve people on the planet.  The only question is... (taking a draft and stubbing out the cigarette)

...how do we arm the other eleven? The camera zooms away from his face, revealing: Yuri alone on a battlefield surrounded by the charred car armored military vehicles and other equipment, discarded ammunition, desert floor stained with what appears to be The faint sound of gunfire, some distance away, carries t wind.

head_text.subj: MOUNTED ON THE BACK OF A BULLET CASING

text: - Gunpowder is poured into a metal casing, lead slug moun A BULLET is born.  A perfect 39mm. - The BULLET travels along a conveyor belt with thousands identical siblings in a Ukrainian factory so grey it's mo - The BULLET, picked up by a ham-fisted UKRAINIAN FACTORY tossed into a crate. - The BULLET, lying in its open crate, rolls down a chute inspected by a UKRAINIAN MILITARY OFFICER holding a manif seems to stare directly at our BULLET.
(to his SUBORDINATE carrying a manifest, in Ukrainian)

Call it "agricultural machinery". - The BULLET's crate rattles around in an open-bed truck industrial road, passes a decapitated statue of LENIN. - The crate containing our BULLET is placed on a ship in the cold grey Odessa harbor.  A container door closes, pl bullet into darkness. - The door re-opens.  The BULLET, still in its crate, now bright, tropical sunshine, surrounded by an azure sea. - The crate is removed by a pair of slim, dark hands, rev glimpse of the bustling, weathered port of Abidjan in the Coast.  The crate is one of dozens unloaded from the ship - BULLET's POV from another open-air truck, now slogging mud-clogged road in lush rainforest. - The BULLET is unloaded from the truck in Freetown, Sier immediately grabbed by the young HAND of a RUF soldier. - The BULLET is loaded into a 30-round magazine which is into an AK-47 machine gun. - The BULLET waits - in the gloomy chamber.  Suddenly, fr the sound of raised voices and gunfire. - The BULLET and its neighbors start to rise quickly up t towards the chamber as the Kalashnikov is fired. - Our hero BULLET is next.  Will it see action? - Smack.  The gun's bolt strieks the explosive cap, gunpo ignited, the BULLET driven out of the barrel. - Shed of its casing - now only a slug - the BULLET emerg bright sunshine.  It is flying down the main street in Fr - The BULLET gives us a perfect point-of-view of the bull it.  They are both flying towards their intended target - eyed CHILD SOLDIER, a boy no more than twelve, firing an almost as tall as he is. - The leading bullet narrowly misses, whistles past the b striking the whitewashed wall behind - one more pock-mark building riddled with pock-marks. - Our BULLET, following close behind, finds its mark, sla the boy's forehead just above his left eye - his expressi relieved. - The BULLET carves through the lobes of the boy's brain where it is enveloped in blood, finally plunged into darkness - the bullet's final resting place.
"Towards A Brighter Socialist Future", reads a billboard street. Fifteen-year-old YURI walks into frame.  He spies a long snaking away from the door of a barren grocery store.

I was born Yuri Orlovitch in the city of Odessa in a country that no longer exists. You might have heard of it - a little place called the Soviet Union. A YOUNG COMMUNIST sits in the shadow of a statue of Trots Soviet-style plaza, jacket and neckerchief removed in the poring over a Communist text.  Yuri approaches, pretends interested in the statue, glances to the Young Communist'
(in subtitled Ukrainian, looking over the idealist's shoulder)

All property is theft. The Young Communist nods at this kindred spirit.  Yuri pa comrade on the back, taking the opportunity to steal the neckerchief and Lenin pin. INT.  GROCERY STORE.  DAY. Now wearing the pin in his own jacket along with the neck a stern expression, YURI strides to the front of the line store.

Where I grew up, everyone was equal.  Some were just more equal than others. The female STORE CLERK is about to order Yuri to the back line when Yuri flashes the pin. Intimidated, the Clerk smiles and pulls a special tray fr the counter.  In contrast to the meager offerings on the the tray contains bags of sugar, coffee, bananas, even Pe INT.  APARTMENT - ODESSA.  DAY. A Soviet-style apartment building.  Front door opens - YU shopping bag in hand. His mother, IRINA, pokes her head out of the kitchen.  Yu a banana.
(in subtitled Ukrainian)

Shortages?  What shortages? Irina shakes her head in amazement. INT.  APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM.  DAY. While a parade of weapons in Red Square plays silently on controlled TV, father ANATOLY and Military Cadet older br VITALY, shoulder bandaged, sit at a tiny table, drinking and listening intently to an illegal shortwave radio - co for antenna.

My father was a wounded hero of World War Two, my younger brother was wounded in Afghanistan - a war without heroes.  I'd gotten out of military service due to a heart problem - it wasn't completely a lie. YURI joins them, careful not to interrupt the broadcoast. He goes to pour himself a glass of vodka.  Without lookin the radio, his father's hand grasps Yuri's in a vice-like preventing him from lifting the bottle.
(impossibly upper-crust British accent)

--Finally, in response to human rights protests and in an effort to encourage the United States to sell grain to the Soviet Union after two successive crop failures, it is reported that the politburo has consented to permit a limited number of Jews to emigrate from the Soviet Union to Israel. (beat)
And that concludes this edition of news from the BBC World Service. Anatoly, deep in thought, switches off the radio.  IRINA puts Yuri's "feast" on the table. They speak Ukrainian, subtitled.
(incredulous)
Trading Jews for grain.
(reaching for a banana)
It's good P.R. - for the Moscow Olympics.
(shrugs)
Good for the Jews.
And us. All eyes to Yuri, family confused. YURI (cont'd) (matter-of-fact)
We're Jewish.
(scoffing)
We're not Jewish.
(shrug)
We're Jewish if we say we're Jewish. The stunned family stares at him - out of the mouths of b finally breaks the silence, pours Yuri a drink.
Mazeltov. Yuri and the family drink to their new identity. EXT.  CEMETERY, ODESSA.  DAY. A sea of Jewish gravestones. YURI and ANATOLY bribe the cemetery CUSTODIAN.

There have been few occasions in the twentieth century when it's been an advantage to be a Jew. Under his father's watchful gaze, Yuri takes a rubbing fr the headstones - "ORLOV". INT.  UKRAINIAN GOVERNMENT OFFICE.  DAY. ANATOLY, with YURI at his side, presents the rubbing alon other crudely forged paperwork confirming their Jewish an CLERK.  "ORLOVITCH" now "ORLOV".

The rubbing from the Jewish headstone was my first forged document.  Little about my life has been kosher ever since. The Clerk gives Anatoly and Yuri the once-over, then stamps an emigration visa. INT.  APARTMENT, BEDROOM.  NIGHT. Suitcase in hand, YURI surveys his bedroom for the last t A car horn.  He glances through the window to the communi plaza below.  ANATOLY beckons impatiently to Yuri.  VITAL load overstuffed suitcases into an old Russian sedan driv old Russian Military Officer, UNCLE DMITRI. Yuri stares at himself in the mirror.  He replaces his st pin for a necklace - a Star of David. INT.  BEN GURION AIRPORT - TEL AVIV.  DAY. CLOSE UP on a heavily-retouched photograph of GOLDA MEIR. still not pretty. YURI stares up at it.
We Russian Jews were supposed to be headed for Israel but I didn't see much of the country on that first trip. We reveal he is standing in a jam-packed, standing-roam-o "TRANSIT" lounge.

Real Jews or fake Jews, eighty-five percent of us ended up in that other "promised land". The Pan American destination board reads: "PA 447 to NEW EXT.  BRIGHTON BEACH - "LITTLE ODESSA".  DUSK. In the distance, a roller coaster in Coney Island, silhou against the afternoon sky. The camera travels off the coaster to a restaurant, apart it.

We congregated in New York's Brighton Beach because of its similarity to the Crimean Sea.  I've always thought it's appropriate we moved next door to the circus. INT.  "CRIMEAN RESTAURANT" - LITTLE ODESSA.  DAY. A typical Jewish establishment with all its paraphernalia on the mantle, etc.  The family sits in a small dining ro attached to the restaurant.  ANATOLY reads the Torah as h for dinner with YURI and VITALY.

I had no idea my father would take his assumed identity so much to heart.  I guess he just stayed in character. YURI, older, as we now know him, studies school work.  Lo VITALY watches "Band Aid" on TV. IRINA puts a plate of mussels in front of Anatoly.
(glaring at the plate, incredulous)
How many times--I can't eat shellfish.  It's "treyf".
You're not Jewish.
I like it. (picking up his felt fedora)
I like the hat - to remind us there's something above us.  I like that. Anatoly dons his hat. ANATOLY (cont'd)
I'm going to temple.
You're not going to temple.  You go to temple more than the rabbi! Vitaly begins eating his father's plate of mussels.  Yuri father exit.
I was suffering an identity crisis of my own. We focus on orientation booklets from a careers fair.  Yu between the eagle of the CIA and the dove of the U.N.

My gift for languages made me highly sought after.  The C.I.A. and U.N. were both heavily recruiting Russian immigrants. Yuri settles on the dove. EXT.  UNITED NATIONS.  DAY. The idealistic YURI, ill-fitting suit, full of optimism, the United Nations Building.

Naturally, I went with the U.N.  They were paying more. He strides past Luxembourg's gift to the U.N. - a sculptu with its barrel tied in a knot.  Never gives it a look. He is greeted at the entrance by an attractive female U.N VIVIAN CARLISLE.  She likes what she sees. INT.  ARMORED PERSONNEL CARRIER.  DAY. The blue helmeted YURI is seated in a white U.N. armored carrier, the background behind him morphs from one Third World location to another: Third World desert to Third World rainforest to Third World slum.

The fastest way to find out you can't change the world is to actually go there. EXT.  NRFL REBEL HEADQUARTERS - NORTHERN LIBERIA.  DAY. Poolside at a recently-captured Southern-style colonial m long way from Georgia.

West Africa's Liberia, or "land of the free", was originally established in the 1800's as a homeland for freed American negroes.  It's been enslaved by one dictator or another ever since.  They even copied their masters' Southern architecture. A tatty pile of weapons - some from World War II - sits i a long negotiating table. YURI, blue beret, observes the CHIEF U.N. ENVOY at the ta opposite warlord ANDRE BAPTISTE, leader of the National Revolutionary Front of Liberia (NRFL). Baptiste, 40's, is an imposing figure.  In full uniform d heat, he wears a jacket one size too small as if he canno extra few pounds.  His THIRD WIFE stands next to him, wip sweat from his brow like an intermittent windscreen wiper

It was my first meeting with the American- educated Andre Roosevelt Baptiste.  While the warning signs were all there, no one had any idea what a monster he would eventually become.  I certainly didn't think he would become my friend. Baptiste has a U.N. document in front of him, awaiting hi signature, clearly enjoying his moment in the sun.
(referring to the meager pile of weapons)
--With all due respect, Mr. Baptiste, you don't seriously expect us to believe that this represents your entire arsenal. Baptiste shrugs. U.N. ENVOY (cont'd)

This is making a nonsense of the embargo ratified by all five permanent members of the Security Council.  The escalation in the build up of arms jeopardizes not only order in the region but ultimately world order. Baptiste smiles.
(playing to the gallery)
--World order?  You say we jeopardize world order? Baptiste's Third Wife wipes his brow. BAPTISTE (cant'd)
Your idea of world order is when you're giving the orders to the world. The Envoy has no response. Baptiste rises from the table, leaving the unsigned docum there. BAPTISTE (cant'd)
Excuse me. Baptiste is accompanied by two armed BODYGUARDS.  Yuri's officer, CAPTAIN VIVIAN CARLISLE, motions for one of her follow - Yuri.
(irritated by Yuri's presence)
I am only going to the restroom.
(shrug)
Orders. They reach the door marked, "MEN".
(aside to his bodyguards as he enters)
This is what they mean by U.N. Observer? Yuri winces at the remark. INT.  PRESIDENTIAL MANSION RESTROOM.  DAY. BAPTISTE pisses at a urinal.  YURI and the BODYGUARDS han respectful distance.
(taunting Yuri)
Aren't you going to help me hold my cock?
(glancing towards the urinal)

Doesn't look like a job for two men. The BODYGUARDS stiffen at the insult.  Baptiste stares Yu a moment, then suddenly bursts into laughter.  The TWO BO also start to laugh - cautiously. Baptiste washes his hands, stares at Yuri in the mirror,

You know you are fighting a losing battle, my young friend.  War is nature.  If you take away the guns, we will kill each other with knives.  Take away the knives, we will kill each other with sticks.  Take away the sticks, we will kill each other with your peace treaties. (turning to face Yuri)
You cannot stop this bath of blood.
It's not "bath of blood".  It's, "blood bath".

Thank you.  But I like it my way. Baptiste smiles and exits, leaving the words ringing in Y EXT.  U.N. COMPOUND - MONROVIA.  DAY. A pep rally for the mostly male U.N. PEACEKEEPERS.  A sta erected in the rundown Embassy grounds.  They chant and s impatiently. A U.N. OFFICER, acting as M.C., approaches the microphone
(battling the microphone's feedback)

And now, we have a surprise for you.  The 83rd West African Peacekeeping Corp is proud to present, all the way from El Salvador, the newly crowned Miss World, Ava Cordova. From behind a jerry-rigged curtain appears the vision tha CORDOVA.  She wears a dress that appears to have been sew She is obscenely beautiful in the squalid setting. The peacekeepers roar and whistle their approval.  YURI, of the stage, is hypnotized. Standing closer to Yuri than necessary, despite the crush VIVIAN CARLISLE (attractive in her own right but pales in with the Goddess on stage).  She catches Yuri's reaction.
(chanting to Ava)
Take it off, baby!  Take it off! Ava steps up to the microphone.
(referring to the sea of U.N. berets)
Baby blue.  My favorite color! A roar of approval from the men. AVA (cant'd)
I suppose I could give you the speech about "my hope for world peace" but I have a feeling you don't want to hear that today.
(calling out)
My hope is for a piece of your ass! They roar again.
(laughing it off)

I don't know if you'll be taking me to bed tonight, darling, but you can take her. Ava unfurls a life-size poster of herself in a swimsuit, flirtatiously holding it up against her body.  She tosses posters to eager hands. AVA (cant'd)

You're all doing a great job - keep it up.  Enjoy the show! On stage, a generic-looking ROCK GROUP starts to play a c the 80's - Tears For Fears' "Shout".  Ava dances enthusia provocatively. Ava appears to make eye-contact with Yuri - blowing a kis direction.  He is paralyzed.
BACKSTAGE, YURI and other Peacekeepers observe AVA escort a huge, American car.  An inebriated U.N. PEACEKEEPER tri her attention.
Ava!  Ava! As the young man reaches out to her, a slick, handsome BU MANAGER shoves him aside.
Don't touch what you can't afford. The Manager slips into the car beside Ava.  The U.N. Peac Yuri watch the car roar away.
(regretting indulging the fantasy)

Let's get drunk. EXT.  DOWNTOWN MONROVIA - BAR.  NIGHT. YURI and two other U.N. PEACEKEEPERS get loaded on local local PROSTITUTES - one of the peacekeepers pouring beer prostitute's throat. From the shadows across the street, a LIBERIAN MAN observ group. Yuri's colleagues toss some Liberian dollars at a waiter drunkenly away from the bar, leaning for support on the P YURI remains at the verandah, exchanges a smile with a YO PROSTITUTE, at least two years from legal. He's tempted.  He knocks back his drink.  He approaches t presses a few bills into her hand.  She picks up her purs leave with him but he motions her to stay.
(referring to the money)
What's this?
(explaining the tip)

For the smile. Yuri exits alone.  The Liberian Man, across the street, f EXT.  DOWNTOWN MONROVIA - STREET.  NIGHT. YURI walks down a poorly-lit sidestreet.  He feels someth back - stops abruptly.  His hand reflexively goes to his Empty. He turns.  The young LIBERIAN MAN is holding him up with gun.
(mixing English and French)
Fuck, no, no, no, no--fuck, no.  Money?  You want money? (going through his pockets, he starts pulling out loose bills)
Fuck, no.  Don't shoot.  Don't shoot me. Fuck.  U.S. dollars. (referring to the face on a five dollar bill)
President Lincoln. The Liberian puts his finger to his lips to hush Yuri. The Liberian appears more interested in the gun than the
(in flawless English)
Glock .45. The Liberian produces a crisp U.S. twenty dollar bill of offers it to Yuri. LIBERIAN MAN (cont'd) (referring to the face on a twenty dollar bill)
Jackson.
What? Yuri stares at the money, bewildered.
President Jackson. He shakes his head.
No.
(misinterpreting him)
You are driving a hard bargain. He hands Yuri a second twenty.
(flabbergasted)
No, keep it.  Keep the money.  Keep the gun.
(offended)
What do you take me for - a thief? The Liberian stuffs the money in the pocket of the bewild Yuri.
Demand and supply. (referring to the gun)
There is more I am thinking where this comes from.
(incredulous)
You want more Glocks?
And the Heckler & Koch G-3 assault rifle.
What makes you think I'll do that?
(quizzical)
I will come back and shoot you with the Glock. (checking the magazine, referring to the bullets)
By the way, do you have the hollow point cartridges? Yuri stares at the man.
(facetious, nodding to the gun)
You got any color preference for that?
(missing the sarcasm, regarding the gun)
Kelly green. (meeting Yuri's eye)
I will find you. The Liberian walks away, still admiring his new weapon. after him.

He'd come to the right place - peacekeepers are armed to the teeth.  And nothing but premium product.  The U.N. mostly buys from Switzerland - where else? INT.  CAPTAIN CARLISLE'S PRIVATE QUARTERS.  NIGHT. CLOSE ON two blue helmets lying beside each other. YURI and CAPTAIN VIVIAN CARLISLE are under the mosquito n bed in her private quarters - trying to get each other ou respective clothes as fast as possible - mouths and hands everywhere. Even in the heat of the moment, VIVIAN is unable to compl go of her work.
(between heavy breaths)
What are we doing here, Yuri?
(kissing her nipple)
Whatever you want.
You know what I mean.  Here, in this country.  Are we doing any good?
(finally telling her what she wants to hear)
Would nothing be better? Satisfied with the answer, she completely gives in to the passion - pulls him to her.

VIVIAN, satiated, dozes amongst the rumpled sheets, backs exposed. YURI uses the opportunity to take an impression of the ke to her belt. EXT.  EMBASSY COMPOUND.  NIGHT. A white armored personnel carrier sits unattended. The LIBERIAN MAN and two COLLEAGUES approach the carrier' opens with their newly-made key. The men start to unload the weapons inside the carrier, s box of ammunition in their haste. The camera drifts off the carrier to reveal YURI, behind barracks, counting a thick wad of U.S. dollars. Spying a lone BULLET on the ground, Yuri picks it up.  We made a decision from which there is no return.
The BULLET has been turned into a pendant, replacing Yuri David. YURI, wearing a sharp, new suit, enters the family restau table of CUSTOMERS - not exactly a thriving concern.

The starting salary for a U.N. interpreter back then was $32,000.  I made fifty K on "misplaced" weapons on that one trip alone. I doubt the Secretary General noticed.  The U.N. spends more on lunch. Yuri kisses father and Maitre d', ANATOLY, who is adding decoration to the window.  He bear hugs mother, IRINA, ne causing her to drop the plates she is carrying.
My tour as a peacekeeper was the perfect preparation for war. Irina notices the change in her son's appearance.
(calling after him)

Who are you?  You're not my son.  My son doesn't own such a suit. Yuri flashes his killer smile in response. Out of their sight, he slips a hundred dollar bill into t register and breezes into the kitchen. INT.  "THE CRIMEAN" RESTAURANT - KITCHEN.  DAY. VITALY, now chef in the family business, prepares a Russi in a kitchen unlikely to pass a health inspection. YURI tastes the food, pretends to gag, spits it out in th Vitaly affectionately cuffs his older brother - the joke obviously a familiar ritual. Yuri takes his brother to the kitchen's rear door. EXT.  "THE CRIMEAN" RESTAURANT.  DAY. At the back of the restaurant, YURI and VITALY sit on the amongst the garbage cans.
You know who's going to inherit the earth? Vitaly looks at him blankly. YURI (cont'd)
Arms dealers - because everybody else is too busy killing each other. YURI plonks a glossy arms brochure in front of Vitaly.  H the contents.
(regarding his brother)
It's a hell of a fucking career move.
That's the point.  I've seen how the world's coming apart.
And you want to help with that?
You can't stop it. (warming to his theme)
It's a basic human need - we eat, sleep, sleep with each other and what else?  Fight. The oldest human skeletons have spearheads in their rib cages. Vitaly is still skeptical.
What do you know about guns?
(joking darkly)
I know which end I'd rather be on. (adopting a serious tone)
Every day there are people shooting at each other.  I think to myself, what guns are they using?  Why not mine?
(hesitant)
I don't know.
(pressing his argument)
Vitaly, I've tasted your borscht, you're no fucking chef.  I can eat here for free and I still don't eat here.  You're doing nothing with your life.
Maybe doing nothing's better than doing this. (referring to an image of a gun)
Yuri, I've actually fired one of these things. Yuri puts his arm around his brother's shoulder.
That's why I need you. (coaxing)
Brothers in arms. Vitaly smiles, looks sold. EXT.  ISRAEL CENTRAL TEMPLE - BRIGHTON BEACH.  DAY. ANATOLY makes his way to the synagogue.  YURI, hastily ad yarmulke, falls into step.
(pleasantly surprised)
Finally getting in touch with what's important, my Son?
(simply)
Yes. However, instead of the synagogue, he is fixed on another distinguished Jewish man, ELI KURTZMAN, on a street corne his way to temple.
It wasn't God I was trying to get close to. Anatoly introduces Yuri to Eli, who regards Yuri warily.
Dad's contacts at synagogue landed me my first Israeli-made Uzis and an introduction to the biggest of the big guns.

head_text.subj: THE UNDERCARRIAGE OF A TWA 747, TAKING OFF FROM

text: A platoon of attractive YOUNG WOMEN in camouflage mini-dr the latest sniper rifles and grenade launchers. An ASIAN BUSINESSMAN pitches hardware to YURI.  VITALY is interested in the girls.
(brochure in hand)

--I can get you the shoulder-fired SA-7 surface-to-air missiles.  The older Chinese model.  Not so effective against modern military aircraft but deadly if used against a commercial airliner.  I'm giving them away at eight-fifty. Yuri notices that his vendor's attention has wandered to older gentleman, SIMEON ZAHAROFF, surrounded by eager VEN nationalities.  The Asian man joins the enthusiastic thro

It was the eighties and the Cold War was far from thawed.  Most of the deals were government-to-government.  There were some go- betweens - freelancers - but it was a mostly private club with a lifetime club president. Yuri drags Vitaly away from the sales girls.

That's him.  The guy Eli told me about.  Simeon Zaharoff.  Brokered deals in the Iran/Iraq war - both sides, sold missiles to Argentina in the Falklands.  Hets a fucking legend.  I've got to talk to him. Yuri pushes past Zaharoff's entourage.
Simeon!  Simeon! A BODYGUARD tries to step between Yuri and Zaharoff.
(stepping between the bodyguard and Yuri)
They're talking. Zaharoff, irritated, nonetheless humors Yuri.
May I help you?
A mutual friend, Eli Kurtzman from Brighton Beach Import-Export said to contact you.  I have a business proposal.  Perhaps we can discuss it - over a drink. Simeon looks him up and down.
You're in the wrong place my young friend. This is no place for amateurs. Simeon walks away without another word.  Vitaly shrugs. fumes.
(under his breath in Ukrainian)
Yob tvayu mat.  (Subtitled - Motherfucker.) Yuri watches Simeon go, surrounded by flunkies.
Curious how you always revert to your native tongue in moments of extreme anger...
Camouflage minidress and beret are now discarded on the f contrast to the blue helmet seen earlier.

...and ecstacy. YURI and VITALY are getting it on with two SALES GIRLS. We pan from one couple in the living room, Vitaly, to the the bedroom, Yuri. We focus on Yuri, in the midst of the act - hears his bro moans in Ukrainian.
Boh...Boh.  Oh, Boh! (Subtitle:  God...God. Oh, God!) Yuri smiles at Vitaly's cries.  Something catches Yuri's
showing images of the aftermath of the suicide bombing at barracks in Lebanon.

Vitaly and I found our niche in under-the- counter gunrunning - regimes suffering under sanctions. EXT.  STREET - BEIRUT, LEBANON.  DAY. A street lined with shelled buildings. Through one of the shell holes, we glimpse YURI and VITAL LEBANESE CUSTOMER.

The job wasn't so different trom the U.N.  I was just as neutral working for the ununited nations.  An equal opportunity "merchant of death", I supplied every army but the Salvation Army. We track with them, only getting occasional glimpses thro holes as they make their way through the war-torn streets Lebanon.

We got our start in Lebanon after the suicide bombing. They enter a building carrying a crude rendering of a Cok "Taste Life."  The model drinking the Coke is Ava Cordova INT.  BEIRUT WAREHOUSE.  DAY. Inside the warehouse is a ten foot high, unruly pile of j weapons.

When the United States leaves a war zone, they generally don't take their munitions. It costs more to bring it back than buy new stock. YURI and VITALY usher the CUSTOMER over to an industrial loaded with assorted weapons.
I sell by the kilo. The CUSTOMER checks the combined weight of the weapons. YURI (cont'd) (shrug)
They're second-hand weapons but they're still okay. Both men pullout calculators and start haggling over the

For all my language skills, I soon discovered that what talks best is money. As long as you can speak dollars, dinars, drachmas, rubles, rupees, pesos, escudos, lira, krones, kwanzas, trancs, guilders, deutshmarks, yen and pounds-fucking- sterling, you can communicate anywhere in the world. Money is finally exchanged.  Yuri and Vitaly leave the Cu his munitions pot-pourri. EXT.  BEIRUT WAREHOUSE.  DAY. CLOSE ON a row of military decorations on an army jacket. U.S. Army Officer, COLONEL OLIVER SOUTHERN, in dress unif adjusts the ribbons on his chest in the side mirror of a armored personnel carrier. YURI approaches.  In full view, he hands the Colonel a cu money. The Colonel places the money in the same pocket decorated ribbons. EXT.  STREET - BEIRUT, LEBANON.  DAY. YURI and VITALY walk back along the shelled street, Yuri what's left of the money.
(irritated by the meager amount)
This is bullshit money, Vit - small fucking potatoes.
What do we do, go more legitimate?
No.  More illegal. Vitaly nods thoughtfully.

What I'd give right now for a plate of red cabbage and potatoes. The wall explodes with gunfire. Yuri and Vitaly drop to the ground, money flying. The machine gun fire subsides, a shower of dust, fragment and hundred dollar bills still floating to the ground. Vitaly, first to recover, draws his own handgun, sneaks a through a shell hole. On the other side of the wall, a firing squad of MILITIAM executed one group of MEN, lying contorted, slumped again wall.  Their bound hands and feet give the bodies a macab awkwardness. Yuri is scrabbling in the dust for the cash. The Militiamen prepare to execute another six men.  Men? on one HANDSOME YOUNG LEBANESE BOY, barely in his teens. Vitaly, gun poised, goes to intervene.  A HAND, stuffed w stops him.  Yuri. The brothers' eyes meet.
(whisper, motioning for them to leave)

It's not our fight. Vitaly's eyes well with tears. After one look back to the teenage boy, Vitaly reluctantl - running with Yuri, heads down, away from the scene. As they run, the wall explodes again with gunfire.

- a cardboard cut-out planted in a sand dune. YURI and VITALY carry a crate from a taxi onto the desert Somalia.  A group of MUSLIM FREEDOM FIGHTERS eagerly surr Yuri hands the Leader an Uzi machine gun.

You know, still the resident family fuck-up.
Someone has to do it. They watch Ava in the living room sharing a joke with Vit girlfriend.
She knows, right?
We don't talk about it. Vitaly looks askance. YURI (cont'd) (shrug)

How many car salesmen talk about their work, how many executives at cigarette companies? And both of their products kill more people every year than mine.  At least mine has a safety switch.  If those guys can leave their work at the office, why can't I?
Shit, you're good.  You almost had me convinced. (to his girlfriend, knocking back his drink)
We're going, baby.
Yuri and Ava are alone at the window, overlooking Central hands her a fresh glass of champagne.
(raising his glass for a toast)
To Manet, Monet...and Ava Cordova. Ava grins, goes to drink when she notices two huge diamon laying at the bottom of the glass.
(gasp)
Yuri!
(shrug)
The trip went better than expected.
(fishing out the damp baubles)
Yuri, they're beautiful. (flirtacious grin)
But what am I going to wear them with?
(flirting back)
I know just the outfit. They kiss. INT.  BEDROOM - NEW YORK APARTMENT.  NIGHT. CLOSE UP on the diamonds dangling from AVA's ears.  She w earrings and nothing else as she and YURI make love.

I didn't know how much she knew and how much she ignored.  I was a good provider and as far as she was concerned - loyal.  Despite the other women, I always made love to Ava as if she was the only one. INT.  HELICOPTER - MANHATTAN.  MORNING. From an unmarked helicopter, JACK VALENTINE and his INTER shadow a Mercedes sedan as it weaves through midtown traf INT.  SEDAN.  MORNING. YURI rides in the back seat of the sedan, scouring the wo sections of several newspapers. A thought interrupts his homework. He opens the sunroof a crack, spies the helicopter tailin He closes the roof.
(to the DRIVER)
Take Park. EXT.  PARK AVENUE.  MORNING. The sedan enters the underpass beneath the Helmsley build moment the car hidden from aerial surveillance.
(to the Driver)
This is good. The Driver pulls over, never coming to a complete stop be bails.  Horns blare at the illegal drop-off. YURI (cont'd) (to the Driver from the sidewalk)

Take them on a tour of the Tri-State. Yuri grabs Ava's painting from the trunk and the sedan pu out into daylight minus Yuri - the occupants of the helic the wiser. Yuri hails a taxi. INT.  HELICOPTER - MANHATTAN.  MORNING. VALENTINE observes the sedan cruising through the heart o

Where in God's name is he going?  Is he lost? INT.  PUBLIC STORAGE FACILITY.  MORNING. With some reverence, YURI props Ava's painting against th his private sanctuary, then goes about his business - shu passports, deciding who he will be. EXT.  NEW YORK APARTMENT.  DAY. AVA, dressed in a robe, all smiles, pours herself a cup o She sips the coffee at the window, glances down. In the courtyard below, INTERPOL AGENTS are picking throu garbage cans under the supervision of AGENT VALENTINE.  V curiously examines the toy gun. The smile is wiped off Ava's face.  She makes brief eye-c Valentine before stepping back from the window. Slightly shaken, she picks up the phone and dials.
(into phone)
Vitaly...it's Ava. INT.  COCKPIT - ILYUSHIN-76 CARGO PLANE.  DAY. The cargo hold of an Ilyushin-76 cargo plane.  It's so ov with weapons, many are strapped into the passenger seats.

I was now the best merchant of death alive.  I didn't own my own plane.  I owned a fleet - running guns into Liberia, Sierra Leone or the Ivory Coast at least once a week. Unfortunately, my friends at Interpol were also starting to find West Africa on the map. Most trips I had phoney paperwork.  If the deadline was tight, I had no paperwork at all. In the cockpit, an American PILOT and CO-PILOT keep an id their instruments as they fly over the endless plains of Leone.  YURI sits in the jump-seat, reading the Wall Stre
(to his co-pilot)
--Even taking into consideration the pay-off to the parents, a week with a girl in Burkina Faso is cheaper than a night with a girl in Jersey.
Plus, they're cleaner--
--and a lot of them speak better English.
(shrug)
Personally, I prefer a language barrier-- An unmarked military jet appears through the starboard wi voice on the radio is familiar.
--Charlie, Echo, India.  Descend for landing on heading zero...two...nine. The Pilot picks up the radio, looks to Yuri.  Yuri shakes dialling his satellite phone.  Yuri's call is answered.
(into phone, trying not to sound too desperate)

Colonel Southern, it's Yuri.  Sorry to call you on this number but I've got an Interpol jet and-- The jet outside the window falls back. INT.  A PENTAGON OFFICE.  DAY. A mid-rank office dominated by a computer terminal.  We l COLONEL SOUTHERN's shoulder.  He is admiring a new medal. IN SUITS sit opposite.
(into phone, measured voice)
I can't know you right now.  It's not a good time. Southern hangs up. INT.  COCKPIT - ILYUSHIN-76 CARGO PLANE.  DAY. YURI, hearing the response, explodes.
(gaping at the phone in disbelief)
Not a good time! Suddenly machine gun fire strafes the Ilyushin - bullets through the fuselage, perilously close to Yurirs very com cargo.
Motherfucker! The jet appears again at the window.
(radio)
--Charlie, Echo, India.  Comply immediately. That was your last warning.
Where was the first fucking warning?!
(radio)
Rock your wings if you intend to comply.
(to Yuri, anxious)
I'm putting us down.
(incredulous)
You land and we're all going away!  I don't have paperwork!
(incredulous)
We're in a flying fucking bomb!  They're firing bullets at our bullets!  Forget about going away!  They shoot again, we're going away for good!  I'm putting us down.
(knowing he's right)
Okay!  Okay!--Fuck!! The pilot responds on the radio.
(into radio)
This is Charlie Echo India.  Descending on heading zero two nine. The Interpol jet takes the lead towards a small airport. terrain below, getting his head back in the game.
(pointing out a narrow highway)
Not the airport.  There.  The highway.  It's our only fucking hope.
(concerned)
A pothole could set us off.

Don't underestimate yourself.  You're the best, Tony. The pilot doesn't buy it but reluctantly changes course a INT.  INTERPOL JET.  DAY. From his own wingseat, VALENTINE observes the Ilyushin's landing on the highway.
I can't land there.
(to the pilot)

He can't get far.  I want a truck waiting on the tarmac. EXT.  HIGHWAY.  DAY. A heavily-trafficked highway.  WOMEN carrying water jars heads, a thin COW pulling the carcass of a car, VENDORS s meat, CHILDREN playing war games. The pedestrians look up to see the lumbering Ilyushin mak final approach - they scatter. The Ilyushin weaves on landing, hits a bone-jarring potho INSIDE THE PLANE - boxes of grenades, bullets and other m jump dangerously up and down. Finally, the Ilyushin pulls up safely on the highway, eng shutting down.  YURI's head appears out of the cockpit wi Curious LOCALS, recovered from the shock, are gathering a of the road.
(to the pilots, sizing up the locals)
We're going to be okay. The PILOTS are already halfway out of the plane door, gra supplies as they go. YURI (cont'd) (calling out from the window)
Where are you going?
As far from the evidence as I can. The pilots start running down the highway.

Wait, you idiots!  There's not going to be any evidence!  Stay with the plane! The pilots ignore him - run for their lives. YURI is left alone.  He turns a lever marked, "CARGO BAY" EXT.  CARGO BAY.  DAY. The rear cargo bay opens.  YURI stands beside his incrimi merchandise.
(to the gathering locals)

Help yourselves.  Be my guest.  No charge. One LOCAL MAN tentatively approaches the cargo bay.  Yuri an AK-47 and a box of shells. More SIERRA LEONESE LOCALS emerge from the side of the ro seemingly out of thin air. Yuri hands out more guns. YURI (cont'd) (to other locals)

Take the whole crate. Two men oblige, ferrying the crate away. The other locals become bolder, then brazen. Soon it's a free-far-all.  Men, women and children swarm the plane pilfering the arms and anything else that isn't down - also a lot that is. Yuri has to exit the plane to avoid being trampled in the EXT.  HIGHWAY.  DAY. YURI buys a Fanta from a vendor - exchanging it for a box grenades. He sits on a soda crate for a front row seat at the chaos Yuri has a calculator out - totalling his losses.
(muttering under his breath, shutting off the calculator in disgust)
What a fucking disaster. Yuri sees the pilot seats being stolen.
Hey, not those!  You don't touch the plane! (plaintive moan)

Not the fucking seats... Glancing up the highway, Yuri sees an approaching cloud o VALENTINE and two truckfuls of heavily-armed Interpol Age Too late.  The last of the guns and ammunition are being on the back of a thin cow. Valentine's truck fishtails to a halt beside the stripped Valentine is first off the trucks and into the plane's ca empty. Other INTERPOL AGENTS fan out - futilely questioning loca Miraculously the weapons have vanished into the bush. Valentine calls out to the last fleeing local - a BOY wit lifevest.
Hey, you! The boy stares back, defiantly inflates the life preserve VALENTINE (cont'd) (exasperated)

Forget it. The entire cargo has gone.  An errant bullet falls off a the plane and rolls down the floor - Valentine picks it u YURI sits innocently on his soda crate. A frustrated African Interpol Agent, MBIZI, wound-up by t rushes Yuri - slams him to the ground.
You run from us. (flashing a machete in Yuri's face)
Can you run with no legs? Valentine rushes over, pulls Mbizi off Yuri.
No, Mbizi.  No, no, no. Valentine drags Mbizi out of Yuri's earshot.  Mbizi still piece of Yuri - Valentine preventing him getting to the g
Let me disappear him, Mr.  Valentine.  He is a devil.  Let me disappear him.
I can't do that.
Look where we are.  Who will know?
We will. Mbizi stops struggling against Valentine.
Turn your back, Mr. Valentine.  I will go to hell to stop him.
(gently)
No. (to his Agents)

Find the pilots. Mbizi and another Agent reluctantly head off in a truck. Valentine returns to Yuri who is dusting himself off.  Va handcuffs Yuri himself, picks up the soda crate and sits on it. VALENTINE (cont'd)
I've spent my whole career on the right side of the line.  You're the first man I've encountered who makes me seriously consider crossing it.
What's the charge?
What are you doing in Sierra Leone?
I'm on safari.
(referring to the bullet)
Shooting wildebeests with submachine guns?
Are you with the park service?  Hunting without a license - is that the charge?
You're trafficking arms.
Trading.  But without evidence who can say?
Trade or traffic, you make a fortune by keeping the poorest people on the planet killing each other. (hesitates, unsure whether to waste his breath - wastes it anyway)
Do you know why I do what I do? Yuri remains handcuffed, sitting on the soda crate - dwar cargo plane.  Valentine paces beside him. VALENTINE (cont'd) (ignoring him)

There are more prestigious assignments, you know.  Keeping track of the nuclear arsenals.  You would think it more critical to world security.  It's not.  Nine out of ten war victims today are killed by assault rifles and other small arms - like yours. Those missiles just sit in their silos. Your AK-47 - it's the real weapon of mass destruction. Yuri regards his interrogator curiously.  Despite the sun down, he feels obliged to give him his version of the fac

I don't want people dead, Agent Valentine. I admit, a shooting war is better for business.  But I'd prefer people to fire my guns and miss.  Just as long as they're firing. He regards Valentine with something approaching pity. YURI (cont'd)

I realize the unspeakable things that are done with my weapons.  I also understand the unspeakable things that are done with Williams Sonoma carving knives and Wilson baseball bats and they aren't taking those off the market any time soon.  People will always buy guns.  Why not mine? Valentine appears to have no answer. YURI (cont'd)
Can I go?  You've got nothing on me-- (unable to resist)
--but cuffs. Now Valentine smiles.
I am legally permitted to hold you for twenty-four hours without charging you. Yuri looks away, knows where this is going. VALENTINE (cont'd)

You may ask, why do I bother to do that?  I can assure you, it is not because I enjoy your company.  And you may be surprised to learn that it is not for any vindictive motive.  No. The reason I delay you for every second of the permissible twenty-four hours, is that I am delaying your deadly trade and the deaths of your victims.  I don't think of it as taking a day from you but giving a day to them.  Some innocent man, woman or child somewhere has one more day on this earth because you are not free. Valentine looks to his watch. VALENTINE (cont'd)

See you in twenty-three hours and fifty five minutes. Valentine walks away.  Yuri is left to ponder the notion. We see time lapse photography of Yuri waiting out his twe hours, under armed guard on the highway - stretching his eating a suspicious-looking sandwich, going to the bathro arcing across the sky - all the while his plane is being cannibalized by the locals.  Finally the time lapse slows real time. Valentine returns in a Jeep with Mbizi and other Agents.
You'll be pleased to know your colleagues were no more co-operative than you. Valentine opens the back of the Jeep.  Lying in the back, of the two PILOTS shot and stripped. VALENTINE (cont'd)
The locals got to them before we could. Yuri turns away from the sight.  His handcuffs are remove Returning Yuri's documents, Valentine notices a photo of NICKI in the wallet. VALENTINE (cont'd)

Handsome family. Valentine and the Agents get back in the truck and drive EXT.  HIGHWAY.  DUSK. YURI starts to walk down the deserted highway alone - his plane is now just another carcass in the jungle. A CONVOY of armored personnel carriers barrels past him - U.N. white.  The lead car slams on its brakes, bringing t a stop.  A woman pokes her head out of the window - CAPTA CARLISLE.
(pleasantly surprised)
Yuri!  Yuri Orlov!
(giving her an embarrassed hug)
Vivian...
What are you doing here?
(approaching the window)
You know.  Fighting the good fight.
An aid program?
Uh, yes.  In fact, I've just had some transport problems.  You couldn't give me a ride to Monrovia, could you?
Sure.  Climb in. Yuri steps back into a vehicle with which he is very fami VIVIAN (cant' d)

We're pulling out.  It's too dangerous. It's a shame.  We were really doing some good things. Yuri nods in understanding. INT.  HOTEL AFRICA - YURI'S HOTEL ROOM.  NIGHT. A weary YURI enters his room.  Sitting on the green sofa gagged, face reduced to pulp, silver hair matted with blo SIMEON.
Jesus!  Simeon! ANDRE JNR., a FLUNKY and his CHEERLEADERS appear from beh door, laughing at his shocked reaction. YURI (cont'd)
Andre!  What in heaven is he doing here?
A gift for you. Yuri stares into the old gunrunner's terrified eyes. ANDRE JNR. (cont'd)
You got here just in time.  I was afraid he would die before you got a chance to kill him. He offers Yuri a Beretta.
Me?!
Who do you think informed on you - cost you your plane?  He came to meet my father, hoping to take your place. Yuri spits on Simeon.
You stupid old fuck!
(knowing smile)
He killed your man when he tried to kill you. Andre again offers Yuri the Beretta.
No.
(confused)
You want us to let him go?
No.  No.  I... Andre offers him the gun a third time.  Yuri refuses it.
So you do want him dead.  You just don't want to kill him yourself?  I understand. Andre grabs Yuri and presses the gun into Yuri's palm, cl own hand over Yuri's.
We'll do it together.  A bonding experience. Andre forces Yuri's finger onto the trigger as he aims at terrified Simeon - eyes pleading. Yuri attempts to pull his hand away but Andre is too stro
You can stop if you want - but you do.  Just say the word. Andre stares at Yuri not Simeon. ANDRE JNR. (cont'd)

Say, "stop". Yuri opens his mouth but no word comes.  Andre presses Yu onto the trigger. The gun goes off.  A splash of blood across the sofa's gr upholstery. The gunshot echoes around the room.  Simeon is very dead.
(quietly)
Stop. Andre smiles.
(surveying the blood-spattered room)
I'll get you another room with a nicer view. INT.  HOTEL AFRICA - LIBERIA.  DAY. YURI collapses on the bar - gestures to the BARMAN who im pours a line of cocaine in full view. YURI hoovers it up.

I started doing a lot of cocaine in West Africa.  I wasn't medicating myself.  I was simply playing catch-up.  I was constantly dealing with people who are chemically imbalanced without the aid of chemicals. It's just a matter of etiquette.  It's rude to act sane in a room full of lunatics. The Barman nods to a patron at a corner table - a SEASONE - no more than eighteen years old.
He bought you "brown-brown", Mr. Yuri.
(wiping his nose)
What?
"Brown-brown".
What is it?
(laughs)
A mixture - cocaine and gunpowder.
What does the gunpowder do?
It's magic.  They give it to the small boys before battle - they do anything.
Some other time.
You have to try it at least once, Mr. Yuri. The Barman starts chopping another line.
Why?
(laughing)

Because it's your gunpowder. Sure enough the Barman pours the gunpowder from one of Yu shells into the cocaine. The SEASONED FIGHTER, assault rifle slung over his should intimidating air, sidles up to Yuri - stares him down.  Y option, does a line. He washes it down with a swig from a vodka bottle, raises to the fighter. The Barman puts on a Ukrainian folk song.  Yuri picks out PROSTITUTES in the bar, starts dancing. He drunkenly dances with one PROSTITUTE after another - t almost violent, the prostitutes flung aside, none lasting a few seconds - caught in the arms of the other PATRONS. To Yuri, the bar swims before his eyes. The music stops.  Yuri, wild-eyed, looks at the stunned b
(to no one in particular, whipping his vodka bottle off the bar)
I'm going for a walk. EXT.  MONROVIA.  NIGHT.

head_text.subj: SCENES FROM YURI'S P.O.V. IN HIS ALTERED STA

text: YURI staggers towards the edge of town - still swigging f bottle.

head_text.subj: A ROOM WITH A CURVED CEILING ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF MONROVIA

text: YURI, eyes unable to focus, stares at a WOMAN'S FACE in f him, moving back and forth.  The gyrating stops. Yuri realizes he is lying in the mouth of an enormous cem his back, a prostitute on top of him.  She gets to her fe adjusting her dress. Yuri panics, hurriedly zipping himself.
(a mixture of French and English)
I didn't fuck you, did I?  Did I fuck you?
(in French, as she counts Yuri's money)
It's not what I would call a fuck. The prostitute tosses a couple of bills back to him.  Yur the money, staggers after her.
Are you sick? She ignores him. YURI (cont'd) (screaming)
Are you sick?! Yuri staggers to his feet - wanders aimlessly across a fi

head_text.subj: A DANCE IN DUST SOMEWHERE ON THE OUTSKIRTS OF MONROVIA

text: Two dozen pairs of feet chase each other on a dirt field from a crowd.  The dust clears, revealing a bundle of clo string doubling as a soccer ball.  The game is between tw indistinguishable teams of MONROVIAN YOUNGSTERS on a make field, goalposts constructed from tree branches lashed to YURI wanders onto the field, joins the game without askin players humor him by letting him have the ball. Yuri dribbles up field, takes an enormous swipe at the ba completely, clattering to the ground. The crowd and players laugh.  The game goes on.  Yuri, al but in a far more desperate manner, picks himself up and away.
YURI throws up at the back of a saloon flimsily construct rusted corrugated iron. Rinsing out his mouth with vodka, he is distracted by the two little GIRLS arguing.
They will!
They won't!
They will!
They won't!
They will!
Ask the foreigner.  The foreigner will know. The GIRLS approach Yuri - no older than seven, formal whi hands politely behind their backs.
Hello.
Sir, will my fingers grow back? One of the girls shows Yuri a healed stump where her hand Yuri runs away.

head_text.subj: A MODERN SCULPTURE SOMEWHERE IN MONROVIA

text: YURI passes in front of an abstract arrangement of holes out to be a building pock-marked with gunshells. Suddenly a FACE appears in one of the holes - SIMEON.  Th wound in his forehead still evident.  Yuri gasps.
Simeon. Simeon turns and walks away - revealing a large exit woun of his head. YURI (cont'd)

Simeon!! Yuri pokes his head through the hole but Simeon has vanis turns back to find himself trapped by TWO MEN in flip-flo Gap T-shirts and AK-47's. Through Yuri's eyes the two men look like four.  The two/ through Yuri's pockets, take his watch, shoes. Yuri is oddly compliant - clumsily helping one of the thi the watch. One of the men, tired of Yuri's antics, aims his gun at Y His colleague stops him.
Don't.  He's Andre's.
(keeping his gun raised)
Fuck Andre.
(seemingly beyond caring)
Yeah, fuck Andre. The man fires at Yuri.  The gun jams.  Yuri looks almost disappointed.  The man tries again.  Again the gun jams.
(referring to the gun)
I'm sorry.  They don't usually do that.  Let me have a look.  Maybe I can fix it.
(disgusted)
Fuck off! The man whips the gun across Yuri's face.

YURI, face streaked with blood and dirt, wanders aimlessl the brush outside Monrovia. A HYENA appears on the dirt path in front of him - teeth frenzied eyes. Yuri stares at the wild dog - starts to quietly cry.  Tea down his cheeks. The hyena runs away.  Yuri is alone.

A vacant-eyed YURI sits in the shadow of an enormous stac unloaded from a freighter. A presidential motorcade appears on the dock.  ANDRE BAPT emerges out of his Mercedes Jeep, gun in his hand.  He st Yuri.
Yuri, you fucked up!  I am going to shoot your face off with your own gun. Yuri doesn't flinch.
(unfazed, regarding the man)
Not bad.  Andre's latest double? The man's face falls.  The real ANDRE BAPTISTE emerges fr ANDRE JNR.
(to Yuri, standing beside his uncanny double)
How did you know?
He's too eloquent.
You have no heart. Baptiste brandishes a copy of the New York Times.

Have you seen the news?  They accuse me of rigging elections, but after this in your Florida with your Supreme Court of kangaroos-- CLOSE ON the headline, "U.S. SUPREME COURT REVERSES RECOU ANDRE BAPTISTE (cont'd)
--now the U.S. must shut up forever. Yuri just smiles.
More good news.  That's the last aid shipment.  The war is so bad, the U.N. is pulling out. Andre shrugs.  He regards the inactivity at the dock.
Why is nothing happening?
(reluctant to give his father bad news)
No trucks.  They are trapped on the front lines.

There are trucks.  You just have to get all that food out of them. Yuri gestures down the dock where food is being loaded in marked, "HUMANITARIAN AID" Andre Baptiste and Andre Jnr.  are clearly taken with the
Killing certain humans can be considered humanitarian. (thinly disguised reference to the previous night)
Isn't that right, Mr. Yuri? Andre Baptiste hands Yuri his payment - a slim briefcase a pouch of uncut diamonds.

After surviving the last few days I'd started to feel like I was invincible.  But there was a weapon that could hurt me. INT.  UPPER EAST SIDE APARTMENT.  DAY. From behind the cover of a sofa NICOLAI shoots at an unse finger as the gun. The camera pans around the room to find AVA in an armchai AGENT VALENTINE.
Hush, Nicki. (to Valentine)
I don't believe you. Valentine is unfazed. AVA (cont'd)
Can you prove any of it?  Where is your evidence?
I was hoping you could help us with that. (opens an old file containing a copy of a newspaper clipping, headlined, "Cordova Disappearance" )
I understand your parents died tragically in EI Salvador. (meeting Avars gaze)
That regime has startling similarities to several of the regimes supplied by your husband.

Get out. Valentine rises to leave.  Ava holds Nicolai, her mind re INT.  FASHION SHOW - NEW YORK.  NIGHT. Impossibly thin MODELS strut along a transparent lightbox runway, flanked by SOCIALITES and PAPARAZZI. Projected on the wall behind them, the words, "FASHION AG - Dress Not To Kill" and various images from the world's Each outfit is enthusiastically applauded.

And now, one of the sponsors of tonight's evening, former Miss World, Ava Cordova. AVA appears from behind the wings in a designer gown.  Sh accepts the applause - gradually becomes aware of a proje her face. She turns to see the projected image of a CHILD holding a When she turns back, tears are rolling down her face. INT.  NEW YORK HOUSE.  NIGHT. Back to us, AVA naked, sits on the end of her bed, clothe beside her.
Ava? YURI, still carrying his suitcase, appears in the doorway the case.
Ava, what's wrong?  Where's Nicki?
(still with her back to us)
He's with your parents. Yuri senses something very wrong.
Why aren't you dressed?  I thought we were going out. He finds a robe from the closet - gently places it around pulls it off her shoulders.
(turning back to look at him)
I can't wear the clothes.  I can't wear the jewelry.  I can't drive the car.  I can't live in this house.  Everything1s got blood on it. Yuri pulls the robe back onto her shoulders, walks to the
Don't be so melodramatic. Ava pulls the robe to her, follows Yuri to the window.
Of course I'm melodramatic.  I'm a failed actress, remember?  We need to talk about it.
Why?  We never have before.
Now we do. Yuri notices the Interpol business card on the bedside ta
These people - you can't trust them--
--I've talked to your parents.  Why do you think they don't want your money?  They know where it comes from.  We all know. Yuri sighs, resigned.
I sell people a means to defend themselves, Ava.  That's all.  I don't hold a gun to any one's head and make them shoot--
--Yuri, I see the news.  Sierra Leone--
--I don't sell machetes.
--What do you think is pointing at the victims when they use those machetes?  I see the pictures.  Yuri, the guns are bigger than the boys.
(angered)
There's nothing illegal about what I do.
I don't care if it's legal, it's wrong. Ava meets his eye. AVA (cont' d)
I can accept the drugs.  I can even accept the other women.  I can't accept this. Yuri looks away.
Please stop.
(looks back)
It makes no difference if I stop.  Someone will take my place the next day.
Let them.  We have enough.  You're not that little boy in Odessa anymore, lining up for a loaf of bread--
--It's not about the money.
What is it? He doesn't answer - perhaps he doesn't have one.  Ava loo the window at their expensive view. AVA (cont'd)

I feel like all I've done my whole life is be pretty.  All I've done is be born.  I'm not just a failed actress.  I'm also a failed writer, failed artist, failed businesswoman.  I'm not much good as a mother.  Come to think of it, I'm not even that pretty any more.  I've failed at everything, Yuri. (turning back to him)
But I won't fail as a human being.  I'm leaving. The words finally register with Yuri.
You can't leave.  I'll stop. (as if trying to convince himself)
I'll stop. Ava is skeptical.  He holds her, reassures her. YURI (cont'd)
I've been thinking about it for a while.  A lot, lately. (as if trying to convince himself)
I'm making more from the oil and timber anyhow. (further reassurance)
I'll stop. She interrogates his eyes for the truth.
(pleading eyes)
You will?  You promise?
(deadly serious)
Yes. (changing the subject a millisecond too fast)
Now get dressed.  We'll go out. Ava picks up the dress off the bed. Yuri gazes at her. YURI (cont'd)

By the way, you're wrong about not being pretty any more. She turns back and smiles. EXT.  FIFTH AVENUE AT CENTRAL PARK EAST.  DAY. A YOUNG INTERPOL AGENT, carrying a tray of coffee, approa plain panel van parked outside Yuri's apartment building.

For the next month I stopped running guns. I went legitimate. The van door opens to reveal VALENTINE and other INTERPOL wearing headsets, monitoring a scanner device.  The agent porn to keep themselves amused - except Valentine.
No wonder Valentine was confused. INT.  UPPER EAST SIDE APARTMENT.  DUSK. YURI toys with his old BULLET pendant as he talks on the For once the spreadsheets in front of him deal with oil a

Thank God there are still legal ways to exploit developing countries. With the cordless phone to his ear, Yuri wanders to the k tosses the pendant down a trash chute. Back in the den, Yuri punches a calculator as he continue call.
But the only problem with an honest buck is they're so hard to make.  The margins are too low.  Too many people are doing it. Finally we are privy to the conversation.
